Milt -
	Do you have an image of the deer tsuba you keep referring too? Can  
you direct me to a book I am likely to have where it may be found?
	You raised a question earlier, is the taste in schools like Jingo  
"learned" because the books and teachers all say it is good? I think  
that quality has to be "taught", you have to see and compare many  
fine examples to discern it. The teachers taste though may not become  
the students. Alan makes a good point, in that we have to know the  
tastes of the times to understand why certain themes and materials  
were used and what was seen as masterwork in one era may not compare  
well to those of another time. However we don't have to blindly  
follow the fashions of the past.
	If you like it, you like it. Buy and collect what you like. What we  
see as clunky and rustic in a bad way, appealed to someone at some  
point or your tsuba would not exist. It seems you like it and it  
found you, thats a good thing.
-t
